docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In her response to your April 14 Chatter question, Janice M. Cauwels of Maywood writes that if she could change one thing about New Jersey, she would repeal the New Jersey Health Insurance Reform Act of 1992 because it "disqualified self-employed people from the group health insurance available through professional associations." Her hostility to the act is unwarranted.

headline.main: Point of Health Insurance Is to Spread Risks Around

docs.lead_paragraph: GOVERNOR WHITMAN has finally had to take the budget ax out of the closet. Until now, the Governor has been able to keep her campaign promise to reduce income tax rates without making huge cuts in state spending. She relied in part on creative money management -- lowering state contributions to employee pension funds and stretching out debt payments, for example, moves that she insists were fiscally prudent though critics deride them as gimmicks.

headline.main: A Million Here, a Million There

docs.lead_paragraph: THE patient, a 52-year-old woman, complained of fatigue. Not only did she lack energy but she was also constantly thirsty. The patient was then given a complete physical exam, which lasted an hour. The diagnosis: the doctor (actually a medical student) who examined the patient had a courteous professional manner but had forgotten her reflex hammer, had neglected to examine one of the cranial nerves and needed to be reminded to palpitate certain glands individually.

docs.lead_paragraph: CODE BLUE" -- in medicine, the words indicate a patient has gone into cardio-pulmonary arrest and must receive immediate emergency resuscitation. Recently, an advocacy group of doctors, nurses and patients took the name Code Blue to underscore their belief that, in the words of one of the group's founders, "our dying health care system needs to be resuscitated."

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Homer Babbidge Library at the University of Connecticut in Storrs is far from a work of art. Its cantilevered design has long been plagued by structural problems making the library a permanent construction site. But inside the library, an ambitious program makes sure that there is art on every one of the library's several levels. A complementary pairing this time -- although they're two floors apart -- are the painters Ed Rath and Deborah Muirhead. Appropriate to the library setting, both tell stories.

headline.main: From Trees and Animals to an African-American Burial Ground

docs.lead_paragraph: BILL CLINTON wrote the book on how to run against the economy in 1992, when the country was in a recessionary funk and the now-famous "It's the Economy, Stupid" sign hung in his campaign headquarters. Four years later, he is discovering that it is far harder to take credit for an essentially well-paved economy -- 8.5 million jobs created, exports surging -- that is cratered by one large pothole: the much-documented if inchoate anxiety that jobs are less secure than ever and that wages are going nowhere, unless you're in the loftiest executive suite.

headline.main: Credit Check;Happy Days Are Here Again! Right, Voters?

docs.lead_paragraph: SEVENTEEN years old, recently jilted by a girlfriend, miserable in the gloom of adolescence and certain that all his roads were blocked, Larry Bresan decided to end it all one day in 1991. Or, at least, to make a statement. He swallowed half a bottle of sleeping pills, but not prescription ones. Actually, Larry Bresan recalled a bit sheepishly, they were over-the-counter Nytols, a mouthful of which are sufficient to make you sick enough to wish you were dead, but not enough to do the job.

headline.main: He Could Pay the Bill. Did He Need the Care?

docs.lead_paragraph: AN increase in Long Islanders without health insurance is generating concern that many people are not receiving adequate medical care. The number of uninsured people in Nassau and Suffolk Counties has steadily climbed since 1990, according to the State Health Department. In 1990 Long Island had 207,000 people, or 7.5 percent of the population, without health coverage. Last year the total was 314,000, or 10.8 percent of Long Island.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: "A Double Standard in Health Coverage" (March 17) was on the mark, but it did not discuss how the differences in health coverage between company executives and rank-and-file workers affect the nation's children.

headline.main: When It Comes to Health, Remember the Children
